prior_works.title: Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Models
prior_works.authors: Jonathan Ho, Ajay Jain, Pieter Abbeel
prior_works.relationship_sentence: DiffuseBot’s morphology generator is built on the DDPM denoising process, leveraging iterative noise removal to sample complex soft-robot shapes from a learned distribution.

prior_works.title: Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations
prior_works.authors: Yang Song, Jascha Sohl-Dickstein, Diederik P. Kingma, Abhishek Kumar, Stefano Ermon, Ben Poole
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The SDE view of diffusion models underpins DiffuseBot’s physics-augmented sampling by enabling gradient-based guidance terms (from simulation) to be consistently integrated into the generative dynamics.

prior_works.title: Diffusion Models Beat GANs on Image Synthesis
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Classifier guidance, which steers diffusion samples using gradients of a learned classifier, directly inspires DiffuseBot’s use of simulator-derived performance gradients to guide morphology generation toward functional designs.

prior_works.title: Classifier-Free Diffusion Guidance
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The classifier-free guidance paradigm informs DiffuseBot’s conditioning strategy, suggesting how to balance unconditional priors with task-conditioning while avoiding separate supervisory networks and enabling stronger guidance toward high-performing robots.

prior_works.title: DiffTaichi: Differentiable Programming for Physical Simulation
prior_works.authors: Yuanming Hu, Luke Anderson, Tzu-Mao Li, Qi Sun, Nathan Carr, Jonathan Ragan-Kelley, Frédo Durand, et al.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: DiffuseBot’s co-design relies on differentiable physics to compute sensitivities of performance with respect to morphology and control, a capability popularized by DiffTaichi’s differentiable MPM framework for soft-body dynamics.

prior_works.title: Unshackling Evolution: Evolving Soft Robots with Voxels
prior_works.authors: Nick Cheney, Robert MacCurdy, Jeff Clune, Hod Lipson
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This seminal work establishes voxel-based soft-robot co-optimization of body and brain, providing the evolutionary ‘breeding’ paradigm that DiffuseBot advances by replacing black-box search with physics-guided diffusion and gradient-based refinement.

prior_works.title: SoftZoo: A Soft Robot Co-Design Benchmark for Locomotion

prior_works.role: Benchmark and simulation tasks for soft-robot co-design
prior_works.relationship_sentence: SoftZoo supplies task suites and physically grounded evaluation for soft-robot co-design; DiffuseBot builds on this setting to demonstrate that physics-augmented diffusion generates morphologies with certified performance across diverse environments.

synthesis_narrative:
DiffuseBot’s core contribution—marrying generative diffusion with differentiable physics to co-design soft-robot morphology and control—emerges at the intersection of three research streams. First, the diffusion modeling lineage (DDPM) and its score-based SDE formulation provides the generative backbone and the mathematical apparatus for injecting guidance during sampling. Classifier and classifier-free guidance show how to steer diffusion trajectories using gradients of an auxiliary objective, a recipe DiffuseBot adapts by substituting learned classifiers with a physics-based “certificate of performance.” This conceptual bridge is what enables the model to prioritize functional viability, not just plausibility, during morphology generation.
Second, differentiable physics for deformable bodies (exemplified by DiffTaichi) supplies the mechanism to compute sensitivities of task performance with respect to both morphology and control. DiffuseBot uses these gradients to (i) guide diffusion sampling toward high-performing designs and (ii) perform joint, gradient-based refinement of body and controller—closing the loop between generative priors and physical feasibility.
Third, prior art in soft-robot co-design and evaluation grounds the problem. The voxel-based evolutionary paradigm from Cheney et al. defined the morphology–control co-optimization challenge that DiffuseBot seeks to scale and accelerate. Contemporary benchmarks like SoftZoo furnish diverse tasks and environments to validate that physics-augmented diffusion yields robots with broad capability. Together, these works directly inform DiffuseBot’s physics-in-the-loop diffusion sampler and its differentiable co-design procedure.
